Sami'i came from a ''[[bazaari]]'' family. A co-founder of [[Freedom Movement of Iran]],{{cite book |author=Houchang E. Chehabi|title=Iranian Politics and Religious Modernism: The Liberation Movement of Iran Under the Shah and Khomeini|publisher=I.B.Tauris|pages=156|date=1990|isbn=1850431981}} he was considered among the main figures of the party's more [[Secularity|secular]] faction and had socialist tendencies, like [[Rahim Ata'i]].{{cite book |author=Sussan Siavoshi|title=Liberal Nationalism in Iran: the Failure of a Movement|publisher=Westview Press|pages=103|date=1990|isbn=9780813374130}} ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:People from Tehran]] [[Category:Freedom Movement of Iran politicians]] [[Category:Possibly living people]] [[Category:Year of birth missing]] {{Iran-politician-stub}}

{{Infobox politician |name = Ajamu Baraka |image = Ajamu Baraka at Oct 2016 Berkeley rally for Jill Stein - 4 (cropped).jpg |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1953|10|25}} |birth_place = [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]], U.S. |death_date = |death_place = |birth_name = Ajamu S. Baraka |party = [[Green Party of the United States|Green]] |education = [[City College of New York]]
[[University of South Florida]] ([[Bachelor of Arts|BA]])
[[Clark Atlanta University]] ([[Master of Arts|MA]], [[Doctor of Philosophy|PhD]]) |website = {{url|ajamubaraka.com|Official website}} |allegiance = {{flag|United States}} |branch = {{flag|United States Army}} |battles = [[Vietnam War]]{{cite web |title=Who are the Green Party candidates? |url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/08/17/politics/jill-stein-ajamu-baraka-green-party/ |website=[[CNN]] |accessdate=August 24, 2016 |date=October 17, 2001}} }} '''Ajamu S. Baraka''' ({{IPAc-en|ə|ˈ|ʒ|ɑː|m|uː|_|b|ə|ˈ|r|ɑː|k|ə}} {{respell|ə|ZHAH|moo|_|bə|RAH|kə}}; born October 25, 1953){{cite web|title=Ajamu S Baraka|url=http://quanki.com/person.php?person=06ESTHVAB98|website=Quanki|accessdate=20 September 2016}} is an American political activist and former [[Green Party of the United States|Green Party]] nominee for [[Vice President of the United States]] in the [[United States presidential election, 2016|2016 election]]. == Early life == {{Missing information|high school and university attended|date=September 2016}} Baraka was born in 1953 and grew up on the [[South Side, Chicago|South Side]] of [[Chicago]].{{cite web|title=Amnesty International Death Penalty Opponent to Receive Abolitionist of the Year Award |url=http://www.commondreams.org/news2001/1019-01.htm |website=[[Common Dreams]] |accessdate=August 1, 2016 |date=October 19, 2001 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061122065840/http://www.commondreams.org/news2001/1019-01.htm |archivedate=November 22, 2006 |df= }} He served in the U.S. Army in the [[Vietnam War]]. Upon discharge, he moved to the [[southern United States]], where he became involved in anti-segregation activism.{{cite web|title= Meet Ajamu Baraka: Green VP Candidate Aims to Continue the Legacy of W.E.B. Du Bois & Malcolm X |url=http://www.democracynow.org/2016/8/18/meet_ajamu_baraka_green_vp_candidate|website=[[Democracy Now!]]|accessdate=August 19, 2016|date=August 18, 2016}} Baraka received his [[Bachelor of Arts|BA]] in international studies and political science from the [[University of South Florida|University of South Florida, Tampa]] in 1982 and his [[Master of Arts|MA]] and [[Doctor of Philosophy|PhD]] in political science from [[Clark Atlanta University]] in 1987.[http://elections.alaska.gov/election/2016/Primary/CandidateOEP/23240407.pdf Alaska Division of Elections – Green Primary Candidates] Baraka has noted the importance of [[W. E. B. Du Bois]] in the formation of his black internationalist worldview, and he attended Clark Atlanta, where Du Bois had taught. Baraka also became involved in the Central America solidarity movement, organizing delegations to [[Nicaragua]] in support of the [[Nicaraguan Revolution]]. He then became an [[Amnesty International]] volunteer, eventually moving up to the board of the organization. == Career == From 2004 to 2011, Baraka served as the founding executive director of the [[US Human Rights Network]], a national network that grew to over 300 U.S.-based organizations and 1500 individual members. He is currently an associate fellow at the [[Institute for Policy Studies]] in [[Washington, D.C.]]{{cite web|title=Ajamu Baraka|url=http://www.ips-dc.org/authors/ajamu-baraka/|website=Institute for Policy Studies|accessdate=August 1, 2016}} Baraka has served on the boards of several human rights organizations, including [[Amnesty International]], the [[Center for Constitutional Rights]], and [[Africa Action]]. == Activism == [[File:2011 Vicki Sexual Freedom Award recipients.jpg|thumb|left|Baraka (left) with other recipients of the [[Woodhull Sexual Freedom Alliance|Vicki Sexual Freedom Award]], 2011]] In 2008, Baraka worked with the US Human Rights Network and over 400 organizations to develop a CERD Shadow Report, which concerned US compliance with the terms of the [[International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination]]. They felt the US government's reports did not adequately address [[racial profiling]], displacement from Hurricane Katrina, and land rights for the [[Western Shoshone]], among other issues. A large delegation presented their findings.{{cite web|last1=Dawkins|first1=Tanya|title=Human Rights in the Age of Obama|url=http://www.yesmagazine.org/peace-justice/human-rights-in-the-age-of-obama|website=[[Yes! (U.S. magazine)|YES! Magazine]]|accessdate=August 1, 2016|date=December 15, 2009}} In September 2016, a [[Morton County, North Dakota]] judge issued an [[arrest warrant]] against Baraka and [[Jill Stein]], after the two were charged with [[misdemeanor]] criminal trespassing and [[criminal mischief]] in connection with their protest against the [[Dakota Access Pipeline]].{{cite web |title=Arrest warrants issued for Jill Stein, running mate after N.D. protest |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/onpolitics/2016/09/07/arrest-warrants-stein-green-party/89965374/ |newspaper=USA Today |accessdate=September 7, 2016}}{{cite web |title=Green Party's Jill Stein Charged in N. Dakota Pipeline Protest |url=http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/green-party-s-jill-stein-charged-n-dakota-pipeline-protest-n644326 |agency=Associated Press |accessdate=September 7, 2016}}{{cite web |title=Warrant out for Green Party presidential candidate Jill Stein's arrest in ND |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/warrant-out-for-green-party-candidate-jill-steins-arrest-in-north-dakota/ |publisher=CBS news |accessdate=September 7, 2016}} Baraka had [[aerosol paint|spray-painted]] the word "decolonization" on a bulldozer during the protest. In an interview shortly afterward, Baraka said that he and Stein were "in discussions with our legal team about how we're going to deal with this" and described his action as an act of resistance against "corporate America and the colonial state."{{cite web |author=Dennis J Bernstein|title=Green Party Candidates Face Arrest: An Interview with Green Party VP Candidate Ajamu Baraka|url=http://readersupportednews.org/opinion2/277-75/39068-focus-green-party-candidates-face-arrest-an-interview-with-green-party-vp-candidate-ajamu-baraka|publisher=reader supported news|date=September 10, 2016}} ==Views and writings == Writings by Baraka have appeared in ''Black Agenda Report'', ''[[Common Dreams]]'', ''Dissident Voice'', ''[[Pambazuka News]]'', ''[[CounterPunch]]'', and other media outlets.{{cite web|title=Articles--Ajamu Baraka|url=http://www.ajamubaraka.com/articles|website=A Voice from the Margins|publisher=Baraka|accessdate=August 7, 2016}} Christopher Hooks wrote in ''[[Politico Magazine]]'' that Baraka "has a long history of fringe statements and beliefs."{{Cite web|first=Christopher|last=Hooks|url=http://www.politico.com/magazine/story/2016/08/what-if-the-green-party-stopped-being-kooky-and-started-getting-real-214149|title= What If the Green Party Stopped Being Kooky and Started Getting Real?|website=Politico|date=August 7, 2016}} === Domestic policy === ==== Death penalty ==== Baraka was critical of [[United States President]] [[Bill Clinton|Bill Clinton's]] decision in 2000 to place a moratorium of [[death sentence]]s for the remainder of his term. Baraka stated, "This was a cynical attempt by the president to shift the responsibility for this execution onto the next president [...] Regardless of how they try to spin it, claims by President Clinton and Attorney General [[Janet Reno]] that they are concerned about racial and geographic disparities ring hollow."{{cite news|last1=Sniffen|first1=Michael J.|title=Clinton praised for death-penalty reprieve|work=Daily Breeze|date=December 9, 2000|location=Torrance, California|page=A10}} On May 4, 2001 an [[op-ed]] in ''[[The Daily Oklahoman]]'' authored by Baraka laid out his opposition to the death penalty and the sentencing of [[Timothy McVeigh]] to death for his part in the [[1995 Oklahoma City bombing]]. He wrote, "[Amnesty International] has dedicated 40 years to working with and on behalf of victims on a daily basis, we have the utmost respect and sympathy for the suffering of the families and loved ones of victims of violence—suffering that deserves compassion, respect and justice. [...] However, the killing of McVeigh, like all other executions, will be done for reasons of political expediency and retribution rather than reasons of justice. For while family members of victims are entitled to respect and compassion, courts should not be allowed to become forums for retaliation. This degrades not only our system of justice but also ourselves as human beings, as we then become little better than the killers we seek to condemn."{{cite news|last1=Baraka|first1=Ajamu|title=Death penalty cruel, outdated|work=The Oklahoman|date=May 2, 2001|location=Oklahoma City, Oklahoma|page=9-A}} ==== Disaster relief ==== In 2005, Baraka argued that the victims of [[Hurricane Katrina]] and [[Hurricane Rita]] should be considered "[[internally displaced]]" and given assistance in accordance with internationally recognized rights for such people.{{cite web|title=Spotlight on Katrina and Human Rights Issues|url=http://www2.tulane.edu/news/newwave/101606_spotlight_on_katrina_and_human_rights_issues.cfm|website=New Wave|publisher=[[Tulane University]]|accessdate=August 1, 2016|date=October 16, 2006}} Baraka criticized the U.S. government for its reaction to the [[2016 Louisiana floods]], comparing its "unprepared" response to "the callous response of the Bush administration" after Hurricane Katrina.{{cite web|last1=Baraka|first1=Ajamu|title=Crucial Context: The Floods in Louisiana|url=http://www.ajamubaraka.com/blog/2016/8/20/crucial-context-the-floods-in-louisiana|accessdate=September 25, 2016|date=August 17, 2016}} Noting that natural disasters and environmental hazards have a disproportionate impact on minority and low-income communities, Baraka wrote that "the flood victims in Louisiana deserve real justice that addresses the full spectrum of human rights," including better temporary housing and fair distribution of and access to humanitarian aid. ==== Drug policy ==== Baraka has opposed the [[War on Drugs]], which he believes has caused local police departments to be "militarized" and "unleashed" on minority communities.{{cite web|last1=Baraka|first1=Ajamu|title=From anti-war to anti-imperialism|url=http://www.pambazuka.org/governance/anti-war-anti-imperialism|accessdate=September 25, 2016|date=April 19, 2012}} In August 2016, Baraka said he was in favor of granting clemency to individuals convicted of marijuana-related offenses, calling prison sentences for nonviolent drug convictions "a waste of taxpayers' money."{{cite web|last1=Baraka|first1=Ajamu|title=Community Forum 8/19: Answers to your Facebook Questions |url=http://www.ajamubaraka.com/blog/2016/8/20/community-forum-819-answers-to-your-facebook-questions|accessdate=September 25, 2016|date=August 20, 2016}} ==== Race relations ==== Baraka has criticized efforts to "Americanize" black radicals and to assimilate African Americans into the American middle class, writing: "Saner people would call that process genocide, but in the U.S. it is called racial progress." Referencing [[Black Panther Party|Black Panther]] activist [[Assata Shakur]], Baraka argued that black radical activists could never obtain true freedom "while the American government and American capitalism[https://www.counterpunch.org/2015/09/16/the-yemen-tragedy-and-the-ongoing-crisis-of-the-left-in-the-united-states/ The Yemen Tragedy and the Ongoing Crisis of the Left in the United States] remain intact." In September 2016, Baraka called for an international commission to monitor [[police brutality in the United States]], calling recent killings by police a form of "state-sponsored violence against civilians".{{cite web|last1=Baraka|first1=Ajamu|title=The Body Count Rises: A Call for International Oversight of U.S. Police Killings |url=http://www.ajamubaraka.com/blog/2016/9/23/the-body-count-rises-a-call-for-international-oversight-of-us-police-killings|accessdate=September 25, 2016|date=September 23, 2016}} Baraka wrote that the United States was "in the midst of a human rights crisis, and the Obama administration has been unable to make black lives matter to representatives of the state." ==== Prison abolition ==== Baraka is in favor of [[prison abolition movement|abolishing prisons]], believing that "we can build a society where prisons are not necessary and [[restorative justice]] can be a tool we use as we evolve as human beings."{{cite web|last1=Baraka|first1=Ajamu|title=Who Should be in Prison? |url=http://www.ajamubaraka.com/blog/2016/8/25/who-should-be-in-prison|accessdate=September 25, 2016|date=August 25, 2016}} While recognizing that those who are "imminently harmful" to other people may need to be separated from society, Baraka disagrees with "the barbaric practice of confining people to cells as though they were animals for years at a time." ==== Free trade ==== Baraka condemns the [[North American Free Trade Agreement]] (NAFTA), the [[Trans-Pacific Partnership]] (TPP), and other [[free trade agreement]]s that he characterizes as "[[Neoliberalism|neoliberal]]."{{cite web|url=http://www.counterpunch.org/2015/05/12/stopping-the-trans-pacific-partnership-is-a-black-issue/|title=Stopping the Trans-Pacific Partnership is a "Black Issue"|last=Baraka|first=Ajamu|newspaper=CounterPunch|date= May 22, 2015|accessdate=August 11, 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.counterpunch.org/2015/05/21/black-america-and-the-political-economy-of-neoliberal-trade-deals/|title=Black America and the Political Economy of Neoliberal Trade Deals|last=Baraka|first=Ajamu|newspaper=CounterPunch|date=May 21, 2015|accessdate=August 11, 2016}} Baraka has termed trade deals a "Black issue" both domestically and internationally. He asserts that the TPP "is a weapon to maintain U.S. global hegemony by denying the fundamental economic, social and cultural rights of millions of people in order to benefit a parasitic white minority ruling class in the U.S." He has stated that poverty and disruption of black communities in many US cities and among peoples in [[Latin America]] are the result of NAFTA. === Foreign policy === [[File:Ajamu-Baraka.jpg|thumb|Ajamu Baraka]] Baraka has been critical of the current [[interventionism (politics)|interventionist]] foreign policy,https://twitter.com/ajamubaraka/status/783499498907729920 especially intervening for humanitarian reasons.https://www.commondreams.org/views/2013/06/04/syria-and-sham-humanitarian-intervention ==== Israel ==== Baraka has been a vehement [[Criticism of Israel|critic of Israel]]. In October 2014, Baraka traveled to the [[Palestinian territories]] as part of an 18-member "African Heritage delegation" organized by the Interfaith Peace-Builders group. The delegation issued six "findings and demands" and urged the [[Congressional Black Caucus]] to place pressure on Israel.{{cite web|title=African Heritage delegation backs global resistance to Israel's "21st century colonialism"|url=https://electronicintifada.net/blogs/ali-abunimah/african-heritage-delegation-backs-global-resistance-israels-21st-century|website=Electronic Intifada|accessdate=August 11, 2016|date=April 17, 2014}} The group specifically called the expansion of [[Israeli settlement]]s "ethnic cleansing and 21st century colonialism"; called for an end to [[United States foreign aid|U.S. aid]] to Israel; [[Israel and the apartheid analogy|accused Israel of apartheid]]; and praised the "[[Boycott, Divestment and Sanctions]]" movement as "an essential tool in the struggle for Palestinian liberation."{{cite web|title=Statement of the 2014 African Heritage Delegation|url=http://www.ifpb.org/africanheritage/statement.html |publisher=Interfaith Peace Builders|accessdate=August 11, 2016|date=April 15, 2014}} After making the visit, Baraka wrote that "a negotiated, relatively 'peaceful' resolution of [[Israeli–Palestinian conflict|the conflict]] is impossible" because "the Israeli state has no interest in a negotiated settlement with Palestinians."{{cite web|url=http://www.counterpunch.org/2014/11/19/violence-and-resistance-in-palestine/|last=Baraka|first=Ajamu|title=Violence and Resistance in Palestine|date=November 19, 2014|website=[[CounterPunch]]|access-date=August 13, 2016}} He accused Israel of carrying out what he termed a "brutal occupation and illegal theft of Palestinian land," adding: {{quote|text=During my activist life I have traveled to many of the countries that Western colonial/capitalist leaders characterized as despotic totalitarian states – the old Soviet Union, North Korea, Cuba before 1989 – but in none of those states did I witness the systematic mechanism of population control and scientific repression that I witness in "democratic" Israel. The security walls, towers, checkpoints, and armed settlers created an aura of insecurity and impending assault on one's dignity at any time. I left that space wondering how anyone with a modicum of humanity and any sense of morality could reconcile living in that environment from the spoils of Palestinian dispossession and degradation and how any nation could support the Israeli political project.}} Baraka also questioned news stories about the [[2014 kidnapping and murder of Israeli teenagers|June 2014 kidnapping and murder of three Israeli teenagers]], which Israel blamed on [[Hamas]] members and which led to Israeli air strikes in the [[Gaza Strip]] against Hamas. One month after the kidnappings, which he called a "false flag operation," Baraka indicated in an interview his belief that "the kids were supposed to be kidnapped but they weren't supposed to be murdered. That was an accident. But nevertheless it gave Israel the pretext that they were setting up for, and that was the opportunity to basically attack Hamas in order to destroy the [[Palestinian Unity Government of June 2014|unity government]]."{{cite podcast |url=http://noliesradio.org/archives/85748 |title=Sander Hicks, Jim Fetzer, Ajamu Baraka — on Kevin Barrett's Truth Jihad Radio |website=No Lies Radio |host=Kevin Barrett |date=July 19, 2014 |time=1:22:12 |access-date=August 13, 2016}} Two suspects, both members of Hamas, were killed in a shootout with Israeli forces in September 2014, while a third Hamas member was convicted of the murders in January 2015.{{cite web|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4574284,00.html|title=Inside the raid on teens' killers|publisher=Ynet News|date=23 September 2014}}{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-30697521|title=Palestinian jailed for murder of Israeli teenagers|author=BBC|date=6 January 2015}} In March 2015, Baraka condemned Israeli prime minister [[Benjamin Netanyahu]]'s comments on the day of the [[Israeli legislative election, 2015|2015 Israeli elections]]. Netanyahu had warned supporters in a video posted to his [[Facebook]] page that his government was in danger because "Arab voters are coming out in droves to the polls."{{cite web |url=http://www.politico.com/story/2015/03/benjamin-netanyahu-arab-voter-turnout-116142 |title=Netanyahu: 'Arab voters are coming out in droves' |last=Gass |first=Nick |date=March 17, 2015 |website=Politico |access-date=August 13, 2016 }} Baraka called Netanyahu's words a "racist rant" that exposed "the brutal and immoral reality of the Israeli colonial project" and the "illusion" of a [[two-state solution]].{{cite web |url=http://www.counterpunch.org/2015/03/26/netanyahus-victory-is-an-even-bigger-victory-for-palestinian-solidarity-movement/ |last=Baraka|first=Ajamu|title=Netanyahu’s Victory is an Even Bigger Victory for Palestinian Solidarity Movement|date=March 26, 2014 |website=[[CounterPunch]]|access-date=August 13, 2016}} ==== Syria and Iraq ==== Speaking in 2014 on [[Iraq War|U.S. involvement in Iraq]], Baraka characterized U.S. foreign policy in the Middle East over the previous 20 years as "disastrous" and said that "what has occurred in Iraq was predictable."{{cite web|last1=Moore|first1=Chris|title=Ajamu Baraka Discusses American Involvement In Iraq|url=http://pittsburgh.cbslocal.com/2014/06/15/ajamu-baraka-discusses-american-involvement-in-iraq/|publisher=[[CBS Pittsburgh]]|accessdate=August 1, 2016|date=June 15, 2014}} In a 2014 interview, Baraka stated his belief that the U.S. had a part in creating the “boogeyman” of [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant|ISIS]] “to basically garner significant public support for an argument that says that this monster, these evil forces—that, by the way, we helped to create—we are the only ones that can go in and slay this monster.” Baraka has also asserted that the [[Human rights violations during the Syrian Civil War|atrocities of the Syrian Civil War]] are being "fomented by a demented and dying U.S. empire, with the assistance of the royalist monarchies of the Middle East and the gangster states of NATO." In an interview, he has suggested that control of natural resources, such as the proposed [[Qatar-Turkey pipeline|Qatar-Turkey]] and [[Iran-Iraq-Syria pipeline|Iran-Iraq-Syria]] [[natural gas]] [[pipeline transport|pipelines]], is one of the underlying reasons for U.S. and Turkish interests in the region: {{Quote|text=These are not just geopolitical fights based on principle, but these fights are based on real material realities, real material advantages. So you look at the routes of these various pipelines that are being proposed and actually built to bring natural gas from Central Asia to the European markets. Turkey felt that it was in their interest to make sure that they can influence the best deal possible that will allow them to be positioned to take full advantage of these pipelines. That's one of the reasons many people argue that Syria had to go: that when there were proposals to run these natural gas pipelines from Iran through Iraq and through Syria, that it was a direct threat to some of the ambitions that [[Recep Tayyip Erdoğan|Erdogan]] has for Turkey.{{cite podcast |url=http://noliesradio.org/archives/90073 |title=Ajamu Baraka & Ibrahim Soudy on ISIS & 9/11 deceptions — on Kevin Barrett’s Truth Jihad Radio |website=No Lies Radio |host=Kevin Barrett |date=October 17, 2014 |time=10:00 |access-date=August 13, 2016 }}}} Baraka has rejected the U.S. position that [[President of Syria|Syrian president]] [[Bashar al-Assad]] and the [[Syrian presidential election, 2014|2014 Syrian presidential election]] are [[Legitimacy (political)|illegitimate]]. In an article, he wrote that the idea of Assad's illegitimacy had been "carefully cultivated by Western state propagandists and dutifully disseminated by their auxiliaries in the corporate media."{{Cite web|url=http://www.counterpunch.org/2014/06/04/the-syrian-elections/|title=The Syrian Elections|date=June 4, 2014|website=[[CounterPunch]]|access-date=August 2, 2016}} He further argued that the election was proof that Syrians have "not surrendered their national sovereignty to the geostrategic interests of the U.S. and its colonial allies in Europe and Israel," and accused the U.S. of hypocrisy for supporting [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2014|elections in Ukraine]] but not Syria. [[United Nations]] [[Secretary-General of the United Nations|Secretary-General]] [[Ban Ki-moon]] criticized Syria's holding of an election during an ongoing civil war for undermining a political solution to the conflict,{{cite web|url=http://reuters.com/article/idUSBREA3K0ST20140421?irpc=932|title=Syrian election will undermine political solution: U.N.'s Ban|agency=Reuters|date=April 21, 2014|accessdate=June 4, 2014}} and the lack of independent [[election monitoring]] was widely reported.{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/middle_east/syrian-election-sends-powerful-signal-of-assads-control/2014/06/03/16876fca-eb2a-11e3-b98c-72cef4a00499_story.html|title=Syrian election sends powerful signal of Assad’s control|last=Sly|first=Liz|newspaper=Washington Post|date= June 3, 2014|accessdate=August 2, 2016}} ==== Ukraine ==== Baraka characterized the [[2014 Ukrainian revolution]] as a "U.S.-supported coup" that contained "racist neo-Nazi elements."{{cite web|url=http://www.counterpunch.org/2015/02/18/obamas-legacy-permanent-war-and-liberal-accommodation/|title=Obama’s Legacy: Permanent War and Liberal Accommodation?|last=Baraka|first=Ajamu|newspaper=CounterPunch|date=February 18, 2015|accessdate=August 13, 2016}} After the [[2014 Odessa clashes]], which resulted in the deaths of 42 pro-Russian and six pro-Ukrainian protestors, Baraka wrote that he was "outraged by the murder of people defending their rights to self-determination at the hands of U.S.-supported thugs in [[Odessa]]." He has also suggested that the victory of [[Petro Poroshenko]] in the [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2014|2014 Ukrainian presidential election]] was illegitimate, questioning "what makes the election in Ukraine legitimate when half of the country boycotts the vote and the national army violently attacks its own citizens in Eastern Ukraine who refused to recognize the legitimacy of the coup-makers in Kiev". Two days after the event, Baraka expressed his suspicions that the shootdown of [[Malaysia Airlines Flight 17]] over [[Ukraine]] was a "[[false flag]]" operation, saying: "Someone wrote about three weeks ago that we should expect a major false flag operation in eastern Ukraine that's going to be then blamed on the Russians. And that's exactly what has happened. They're trying to say in the Western press that the Ukrainian government does not have access to that kind of weaponry, when it's clear that they do."{{cite podcast |url=http://noliesradio.org/archives/85748 |title=Sander Hicks, Jim Fetzer, Ajamu Baraka — on Kevin Barrett’s Truth Jihad Radio |website=No Lies Radio |host=Kevin Barrett |date=July 19, 2014 |time=1:31:00 |access-date=August 13, 2016 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2016/08/17/the-wild-beliefs-of-ajamu-baraka-jill-stein-s-green-party-running-mate.html| title=The Wild Beliefs of Ajamu Baraka, Jill Stein’s Green Party Running Mate|last=Resnick|first=Gideon|newspaper=[[The Daily Beast]]|date=August 17, 2016|accessdate=August 17, 2016}} He criticized Western media coverage of the event for "undermining anything coming from [[Russia Today]]. That's where you see the story being advanced that there is a possibility that this story is a little more complicated than people realize."{{cite podcast |url=http://noliesradio.org/archives/85748 |title=Sander Hicks, Jim Fetzer, Ajamu Baraka — on Kevin Barrett’s Truth Jihad Radio |website=No Lies Radio |host=Kevin Barrett |date=July 19, 2014 |time=1:33:40 |access-date=August 13, 2016 }} Baraka also claimed that observers from the [[Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe]] were "sent in basically as spies who showed up on the scene to quote-unquote 'monitor'."{{cite podcast |url=http://noliesradio.org/archives/85748 |title=Sander Hicks, Jim Fetzer, Ajamu Baraka — on Kevin Barrett’s Truth Jihad Radio |website=No Lies Radio |host=Kevin Barrett |date=July 19, 2014 |time=1:34:15 |access-date=August 13, 2016 }} ==== Nigeria ==== Baraka has criticized calls for Western military action against the [[jihadist]] [[List of active rebel groups#Groups which control territory|rebel group]] [[Boko Haram]], arguing that "a purely military response will only exacerbate an insurgency whose roots lie in the complex socio-historical conditions and internal contradictions of Northeast Nigeria."{{cite web|title=Our Girls are Still Not Home: Boko Haram and the Politics of Death |url=http://www.commondreams.org/views/2015/01/30/our-girls-are-still-not-home-boko-haram-and-politics-death |website=[[Common Dreams]] |accessdate=August 13, 2016 |date=January 30, 2015 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151217234107/http://www.commondreams.org/views/2015/01/30/our-girls-are-still-not-home-boko-haram-and-politics-death |archivedate=December 17, 2015 |df= }} In May 2014, a month after Boko Haram [[Chibok schoolgirls kidnapping|kidnapped 276 schoolgirls]] from the northern Nigerian town of [[Chibok]], he expressed skepticism about the official version of events and the number of victims, saying that "even if there was a kidnapping, there's some people who are suggesting that the numbers are in fact inflated."{{cite podcast |url=http://noliesradio.org/archives/82532 |title=Ajamu Baraka: Boko Haram part of US destabilization agenda _ on Kevin Barrett’s Truth Jihad Radio |website=No Lies Radio |host=Kevin Barrett |date=May 20, 2014 |time=10:13 |access-date=August 13, 2016 }} Baraka also stated that while he was "outraged" by the kidnapping, he was also suspicious of U.S. humanitarian concerns in the region: "U.S. policymakers don’t give a damn about the schoolgirls in Nigeria because their real objective is to use the threat of Boko Haram in the northern part of the country to justify the real goal of occupying the oil fields in the south and to block the Chinese in Nigeria."{{cite web |title=From Benghazi to Boko Haram: Why I support the Benghazi Inquiry |url=http://www.blackagendareport.com/content/benghazi-boko-haram-why-i-support-benghazi-inquiry |last=Baraka |first=Ajamu |website=Black Agenda Report |accessdate=August 13, 2016 |date=May 14, 2014 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150921211307/http://www.blackagendareport.com/content/benghazi-boko-haram-why-i-support-benghazi-inquiry |archivedate=September 21, 2015 |df= }} === Terrorism === ==== Views on Je suis Charlie movement==== In a January 2015 essay, Baraka described the [[Republican marches|Republican march]] in [[Paris]] in reaction to the [[Charlie Hebdo shooting]] as a "white power march," and the [[Je suis Charlie]] movement in general as an "arrogant rallying cry for white supremacy". Baraka condemned what he perceived as the disproportionate interest in the Charlie Hebdo attacks, and the relative lack of interest in the [[2015 Baga massacre|Baga massacre]] in [[Nigeria]] by [[Boko Haram]], which took place days before the Charlie Hebdo shooting and resulted in many more deaths. Baraka also criticized the "degrading ritual" of assimilation that Arabs and Muslims undergo in France, the "arrogant lack of respect for the ideas and culture of non-European peoples" that led to the [[French ban on face covering]] in public spaces, and the "racist" and "Islamophobic" character of Charlie Hebdo's recent publications.{{Cite web|url=http://dissidentvoice.org/2015/01/the-charlie-hebdo-white-power-rally-in-paris//|title=The Charlie Hebdo White Power Rally in Paris: A Celebration of Western Hypocrisy|website=Dissident Voice|language=en-US|date=January 14, 2015|access-date=August 7, 2016}} Baraka's "Je suis Charlie" article was republished in January 2016 in an anthology about the [[November 2015 Paris attacks]]. The book, titled ''ANOTHER French False Flag? Bloody Tracks from Paris to San Bernadino'', was edited by Kevin Barrett, a [[Holocaust denial|Holocaust denier]] and [[9/11 Truth movement|9/11 conspiracy theorist]].{{Cite web|author=O'Connor, Brendan |url=http://gawker.com/stein-campaign-says-running-mate-didn-t-realize-he-was-1785157203 |title=Stein Campaign Says Running Mate Didn’t Realize He Was Talking to and Being Republished By Holocaust Denier |website=[[Gawker]] |date=August 11, 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160812003155/http://gawker.com/stein-campaign-says-running-mate-didn-t-realize-he-was-1785157203 |archivedate=2016-08-12 |df= }} Baraka also has appeared at least twice on Barrett's radio show. Other contributors to the anthology (including controversial figures such as [[Gilad Atzmon]] and [[Alain Soral]]) posited "that the Charlie Hebdo attacks and many others were perpetrated by the CIA and [[Mossad]]" as "[[false flag]]s."Yair Rosenberg, [http://www.tabletmag.com/scroll/210549/friends-dont-let-friends-vote-for-jill-stein Friends Don't Let Friends Vote for Jill Stein], ''[[Tablet (magazine)|Tablet]]'' (August 10, 2016). [[Yair Rosenberg]] of ''[[Tablet (magazine)|Tablet]]'' described the work as a "veritable who's who of bigots and conspiracy theorists." In August 2016, Baraka said that he had been unaware both of Barrett's Holocaust beliefs and of the views of some of the book's other contributors. In a statement, Baraka said that he would be "happy to discuss the details" of his own writing, but that he rejected any "smear campaign" based on the authors and contents of the rest of the book. [[Jill Stein]] campaign press director Meleiza Figueroa also clarified that Baraka is not a Holocaust denier. ==== Charleston massacre ==== In an article titled "No 'Je Suis Charleston'?" Baraka contended that a collective response similar to "Je suis Charlie" was absent after the [[Charleston church shooting]] at the [[Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church|Emanuel AME Church]], and criticized Obama for not calling suspect [[Dylann Roof]] a terrorist.{{cite web|url=http://www.blackagendareport.com/no_je-suis_charleston_de-politicization_of_black_oppression|title=No ‘Je Suis Charleston’?: The De-Politicization of Black Oppression|date=June 30, 2015|website=Black Agenda Report|last1=Baraka|first1=Ajamu|accessdate=August 1, 2016}} As a longtime opponent of the death penalty, Baraka has also criticized the [[United States Department of Justice|Department of Justice]]'s decision to seek the death penalty for Roof, saying that it "should be seen as no more than another tactical move by the state as part of the last phase of the counterinsurgency launched against the black liberation movement. [...] By appealing to African Americans, the group in the country most consistently opposed to the death penalty, state propagandists saw this as a perfect opportunity to undermine opposition to capital punishment and facilitate the process of psychological incorporation."{{Cite web|url=http://www.blackagendareport.com/muhammad_ali_and_dylan_roof/|title=Muhammad Ali and Dylann Roof: Contested Meanings and Contested Lies|website=Black Agenda Report|language=en-US|date=June 14, 2016|access-date=August 7, 2016}} === Politicians and activists === ==== Barack Obama ==== Baraka referred to President [[Barack Obama]] as an "[[Uncle Tom]] president" because Obama condemned the 2014 [[Ferguson unrest|riots and violence]] in [[Ferguson, Missouri]] that occurred after the [[Shooting of Michael Brown|death of Michael Brown]].{{cite web |url=http://www.ajamubaraka.com/black-lives-dont-matter-in-racist-capitalist-america/ |title=Black Lives Don’t matter in Racist, Capitalist "America" |last1=Baraka |first1=Ajamu |date= |website= |publisher= |access-date= }} Defending his use of the term, Baraka later said that he was speaking to a "specialized audience" and was attempting to "shock people into a more critical look at this individual."{{cite web |url=https://mic.com/articles/151914/jill-stein-s-vp-doubles-down-on-calling-obama-uncle-tom-in-truly-wild-town-hall |title=Jill Stein's VP doubles down on calling Obama "Uncle Tom" in truly wild town hall |last1=Cahn |first1=Emily |date=August 18, 2016 |website=[[Mic (media company)|Mic.com]] }} Baraka has also argued that Obama has shown "obsequious deference to white power,"{{cite web|url=https://www.popularresistance.org/martin-luther-king-my-dream-is-not-obama/|title=Martin Luther King: "My Dream is Not Obama"|date=August 19, 2013|website=Popular Resistance|last1=Baraka|first1=Ajamu|accessdate=August 1, 2016}} and that Obama and [[Loretta Lynch]] are members of the "black [[Petite bourgeoisie|petit-bourgeoisie]] who have become the living embodiments of the partial success of the state’s attempt to colonize the consciousness of Africans/black people."{{Cite web|url=http://www.ajamubaraka.com/muhammad-ali-and-dylann-roof-contested-meanings-and-contested-lies/|title=Muhammad Ali and Dylann Roof: Contested Meanings and Contested Lies|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}} Baraka was critical of the [[Obama administration]]'s decision to not attend the [[Durban Review Conference|2009 UN World Conference Against Racism]] in [[Geneva]].{{cite web|url=http://www.thestrategycenter.org/radio/2009/05/11/ajamu-baraka-un-world-conference-against-racism-obama-and-us-boycott|title=Ajamu Baraka: The UN World Conference Against Racism, Obama, and the US boycott|date=May 11, 2009|website=The Labor/Community Strategy Center|last1=Mann|first1=Eric|accessdate=August 1, 2016}} In 2013, Baraka stated that inviting Obama to the 50th anniversary of the [[1963 March on Washington]] "should be taken as an insult by everyone who has struggled and continues to struggle for human rights, peace and social justice." More recently, he has argued that "the Obama Administration collaborated with suppressing the 2009 report from the Department of Homeland Security (DHS), which identified violent white supremacist groups as a threat to national security more lethal than the threat from Islamic 'fundamentalists'." In an October 2016 interview with ''[[The Detroit News]]'', Baraka described Obama as a "moral disaster" and one of "the worst things that has happened to African-American people".{{cite web|last1=Baraka|first1=Ajamu|title=Green Party’s Baraka: Obama has been ‘moral disaster’|url=http://www.detroitnews.com/story/news/politics/2016/10/18/baraka-green-party-vice-president/92384566/|website=The Detroit News|accessdate=October 19, 2016|date=October 18, 2016}} ==== Bernie Sanders ==== Baraka referred to the presidential campaign of [[United States Senate|U.S. Senator]] [[Bernie Sanders]] as "media-driven pseudo-opposition"{{Cite web|url=http://www.counterpunch.org/2016/02/11/beyonce-and-the-politics-of-cultural-dominance/|title=Beyonce and the Politics of Cultural Dominance|date=2016-02-11|website=CounterPunch|access-date=2016-08-02}} and "an ideological prop… of the logic and interests of the capitalist-imperialist settler state." In a September 2015 article, Baraka condemned Sanders' foreign policy and his support for continuing Obama's program of [[drone strikes in Yemen]], claiming that "the world that a President Sanders promises" would be one with "continued war crimes from the sky with drone strikes and Saudi-led terror in support of the Western imperial project."{{Cite web|url=http://www.counterpunch.org/2015/09/16/the-yemen-tragedy-and-the-ongoing-crisis-of-the-left-in-the-united-states/|title=The Yemen Tragedy and the Ongoing Crisis of the Left in the United States|date=September 16, 2015|website=CounterPunch|access-date=August 2, 2016}} Baraka argued that support for Sanders represents "a tacit commitment to [[Eurocentrism]] and the assumptions of normalized white supremacy" due to what he perceived as "indifference" to the lives lost during the drone campaign in Yemen. ==== Bill Clinton ==== In June 2016, Baraka criticized the family of [[Muhammad Ali]] for inviting [[Bill Clinton]] to deliver the boxer's eulogy.{{Cite web|url=http://www.politico.com/magazine/story/2016/08/jill-stein-2016-hillary-clinton-republicans-214146 |title=Can the Green Party Win With ‘Jill, Not Hill’?|access-date=2016-08-16}} Baraka described Clinton as a "rapist" and "petty opportunist politician." ==== Cornel West ==== In September 2015, Baraka criticized [[Cornel West]] for supporting Bernie Sanders, saying that West was "sheep-dogging for the Democrats" by "drawing voters into the corrupt Democratic party".{{cite web|last1=Baraka|first1=Ajamu|title=Why is Cornel West Sheep-Dogging for the Democrats Again?|url=http://dissidentvoice.org/2015/09/why-is-cornel-west-sheep-dogging-for-the-democrats-again/|website=Dissident Voice|accessdate=August 9, 2016|date=September 9, 2015}} West later endorsed [[Jill Stein]] after Sanders endorsed [[Hillary Clinton]].{{cite web |url=http://www.democracynow.org/2016/7/18/why_a_member_of_the_democratic|title=Cornel West: Why I Endorse Green Party's Jill Stein Over "Neoliberal Disaster" Hillary Clinton|date=July 18, 2016 |website=Democracy Now |accessdate=August 12, 2016 }}{{cite web |url=http://thehill.com/blogs/ballot-box/presidential-races/287829-sanders-ally-cornel-west-backs-green-candidate |title=Sanders ally Cornel West backs Green candidate |first=Mark |last=Hensch |date=July 14, 2016 |work=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]] |accessdate=August 2, 2016 }} ==== Beyoncé ==== In February 2016, Baraka criticized [[Beyoncé]]'s performance of her song "[[Formation (song)|Formation]]" at the [[Super Bowl 50 halftime show]], which featured [[backup dancers]] dressed as [[Black Panther Party|Black Panthers]], claiming that it was a "commodified caricature of black opposition." Baraka derided the performance as "mindless entertainment" and "a depoliticized spectacle by gyrating, light-skinned booty-short-clad sisters." Baraka claimed that the "white male capitalist patriarchy" was responsible for selecting Beyoncé to perform and would not have allowed "anything subversive or even remotely oppositional to the interests of the capitalist oligarchy" on stage. == Awards and recognition == In 1998, Baraka was one of 300 human rights workers honored by UN Secretary General [[Kofi Annan]]. In 2001, Baraka was named "abolitionist of the year" by the [[National Coalition to Abolish the Death Penalty]] for his efforts to end the [[death penalty in the United States]].{{cite web|title=Ajamu Baraka (VA)|url=http://www.woodhullfoundation.org/about-us/advisory-council/ajamu-baraka-ga/|website=[[Woodhull Freedom Foundation]]|accessdate=August 1, 2016}} == 2016 U.S. vice presidential campaign {{notable|date=September 2018}} {{orphan|date=July 2010}}{{Infobox person | image = | name = Andrew Nebbett | imagesize = | caption = | birth_date = 1963 | birth_place = [[England]] | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = [[Antiques]] expert | spouse = | children = | website = http://www.andrewnebbett.com/ }} '''Andrew Nebbett''' is a 3rd generation antique dealer and specialist in antique [[interior design]] [[solution]]s. He owns a shop which bears his name in [[North London]].<ref name="FT1">{{Citation | last = Brooke | first = Simon | title = Big car, big flat, big on antiques? | newspaper = Financial Times | page = 10 | date = March 8, 2003 | url = }}</ref> In 2003 [[Evening Standard]] magazine listed Nebbett as one of London's top five antique dealers.<ref name="ES1">{{Citation | last = | first = | author-link = | last2 = | first2 = | author2-link = | title = Fashion | newspaper = Evening Standard Magazine | page = 44 | date = 11 July 2003 | url = }} </ref>
Nebbett's grandfather, Albert Porter, was head of the interior design department at [[Harrods]] for over 30 years from 1949-1985.<ref name="ES1" /> Porter's most well known commission was the 1965 complete interior design of the house of [[Brian Epstein]], manager of the Beatles.
== Clients ==
Nebbett’s regular clients include [[Jamie Oliver]] who purchased a 14 ft oak table for his house in Kent, [[Jamie Theakston]],<ref name="FT1"/><ref>http://www.livingetc.com/showcase/houses/Jamie_Theakstons_quirky_town_house_article_277619.html</ref> [[Anouska Hempel]],<ref>http://www.ftd.de/lifestyle/luxus/:how-i-spend-it-anouska-hempel/50024706.html</ref> [[Sean Bean]] and [[Guy Ritchie]]. In 2009 [[Jeremy Hackett]] wrote an article profiling Andrew Nebbett Antiques as his favourite shop in London.<ref>{{Citation | author = Jeremy Hackett | date = February 2009 | journal = Menswear Buyer | title = none|trans-title=| volume = | issue = | pages = | publisher = | location = | issn = | pmid = | pmc = | doi = | bibcode = | oclc = | id = | url = | language = | format = | accessdate = | laysummary = | laysource = | laydate = | quote =}}</ref> Cogs from Nebbett's London showroom were featured in the [[Daily Telegraph|Telegraph Magazine]] in a profile of the home of [[Mark Thompson (theatre designer)|Mark Thompson]] and [[Anthony Ward]].<ref>{{Citation | last = Morgan | first = Dean Rhys | author-link = | title = Dramatic Effect | newspaper = Telegraph Magazine | pages = 76–79 | date = 26 July 2008 }}</ref>
== Projects ==
Current projects include the making of the counters and cabinets for the new [[Goyard|GOYARD]] London shop, at 116 Mount Street, [[Mayfair]].
Andrew Nebbett Designs provides a range of British handmade clothes rails, zinc & copper tables, Bar-back systems, equestrian saddle racks & bespoke commissions.<ref>https://www.andrewnebbettdesigns.co.uk/</ref>
== Exhibitions ==
Nebbett has exhibited at [[Olympia, London|Olympia]] Fine Art and Antiques Fairs, and the Decorative Antiques and Textiles fair in Battersea.

'''Andrés Molina Enríquez''' (November 30, 1868, [[Jilotepec de Abasolo (municipality)|Jilotepec de Abasolo]], [[State of Mexico]] – 1940) was a [[Mexican people|Mexican]] revolutionary intellectual, author of ''The Great National Problems '' (1909) which drew on his experiences as a notary and [[Justice of the Peace]] in [[Mexico State]].{{cite book|last=Joseph|first=Gilbert Michael|title=Revolution from Without: Yucatán, Mexico, and the United States, 1880-1924|publisher=Duke University Press|year=1988|pages=336|isbn=0-8223-0822-3}}{{cite book|last=Toffolo|first=Cris E.|author2=M. Crawford Young|title=Emancipating Cultural Pluralism|publisher=SUNY Press|year=2003|pages=86|isbn=0-7914-5597-1}} He is considered the intellectual father of the land reform movement in modern Mexico embodied in Article 27 of the Constitution of 1917 "by transcending the Liberal taboo against state interference in the ownership and administration of private property."Stanley F. Shadle, ''Andrés Molina Enríquez: Mexican Land Reformer of the Revolutionary Era'', Tucson: University of Arizona Press 1994, p. 2. He has been called "the Rousseau of the Mexican Revolution."Anita Brenner, ''The Wind That Swept Mexico: The History of the Mexican Revolution, 1910-1942.'' New York: Harper and Brothers Publishers 1943, p. 43. ==Influence & work== ===''Los Grandes Problemas Nacionales''=== Molina Enríquez is best known for publishing ''Los Grandes Problemas Nacionales'' (The Great National Problems) in 1909,{{cite book|title=Windows to culture II: a reading comprehension textbook|publisher=UNAM|pages=22|isbn=968-36-6200-5}} a book highly critical of the [[Porfirio Díaz]] government.{{cite book|last=Niblo|first=Stephen R.|title=Mexico in the 1940s: Modernity, Politics, and Corruption|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|year=1999|pages=368|isbn=0-8420-2795-5}} Molina Enríquez characterized the period after 1821 as the era of national disintegration. The book highlighted issues of sharp political divisions, recurrent armed conflicts, and periodic foreign interventions.{{cite book|last=Tutino|first=John|title=From Insurrection to Revolution in Mexico: Social Bases of Agrarian Violence, 1750-1940|publisher=Princeton University Press|year=1986|pages=130|isbn=0-691-02294-1}} Molina Enríquez focused particularly on two aspects, [[land reform]] and the rights of the indigenous people and their place in society socially. Molina Enríquez was arrested by the government of [[Francisco León de la Barra]] on August 25, 1911 for publishing the document, which has later been described as highly influential on the eve of the [[Mexican Revolution]].{{cite book|last=Young|first=Eric Van|title=Hacienda and Market in Eighteenth-Century Mexico: The Rural Economy of the Guadalajara Region, 1675-1820|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|year=2006|pages=xxi|isbn=0-7425-5356-6}}{{cite book|last=Henderson|first=Peter V. N.|title=In the Absence of Don Porfirio: Francisco Leon de la Barra and the Mexican|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|year=1999|pages=181|isbn=0-8420-2774-2}} A well-known quote from the book is "la hacienda no es negocio" [the [[hacienda]] is not a business]: "By this he meant that the large Mexican landed states of his day (and stretching back to their origins in the era of the Spanish conquest) were for the most part not profit-oriented but 'feudal' enterprises, that rural Mexico was therefore only partially capitalistic, if at all, and that the country was ipso facto only imperfectly modern."Eric Van Young, "[http://muse.jhu.edu/login?uri=/journals/ethnohistory/v050/50.1van_young.html Beyond the Hacienda: Agrarian Relations and Socioeconomic Change in Rural Mesoamerica]," ''Ethnohistory'' 50:1 (2003): 231. ===Indigenous rights=== Molina Enríquez argued indigenous people suffered because of position on national social structure. In order to resolve the suffering of the indigenous people, and create equality, Molina Enríquez believed they had to be integrated into the national state, this idea would be central to the indigenist movement when it went international.{{cite book|last=Gray|first=Andrew|title=Indigenous Rights and Development: Self-determination in an Amazonian|publisher=Berghahn Books|year=1997|pages=50|isbn=1-57181-875-8}} Molina Enríquez has been cited as arguing that the only true Mexicans were the [[mestizos]] and that they would be the inheritors of Mexico, classifying the other social group in Mexico as [[Criollo (people)|Criollos]], who were [[Spanish people|Spanish]]/[[French people|French]] in their thinking and ways, the mestizos to Molina Enríquez, were a new race, with a new culture of their own and the majority of Mexicans.{{cite book|last=De Mente|first=Boye Lafayette|title=There's a Word for It in Mexico|publisher=McGraw-Hill Professional|year=1998|pages=xxix|isbn=0-8442-7251-5}} ===Land reform=== Molina Enríquez believed land reform was needed. In August 1911, he issued the Plan de Texcoco as a prelude to revolt, in which he called for establishing a [[dictatorship]] committed to land reform. A version of the Plan de Texcoco was published in the newspaper ''El Imparcial'', which condensed the land reform section, with the Decree over the breaking up of large properties saying
It is declared that on the basis of public utility, from the date of this decree [August 23, 1911], the partial expropriation of all the rural estates with a surface area that exceeds two thousand hectares. Popular action may denounce the real estate that should be expropriated in keeping with this law. The denouncer has the right to choose the best part of the land suitable for expropriation.Plan de Texcoco by Andres Molina Enríquez published in ''El Imparcial'', translation by Stanley F. Shadle. Shadle, ''Andrés Molina Enríquez'', Appendix. p. 114.
The role of the dictatorship would be to parcel out large [[hacienda]]s to individual, not communal claimants. Molina Enríquez would eventually go on to be a key adviser to the committee which drafted [[Mexican constitution#Article 27|article 27]] of the [[Constitution of Mexico|Mexican Constitution]] and a member of the National Agrarian Commission.Stanley Shadle, ''Andrés Molina Enríquez: Mexican Land Reformer of the Revolutionary Era''. Tucson: University of Arizona Press 1994.{{cite book|last=Fowler|first=William|title=Ideologues and Ideologies in Latin America|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|year=1997|pages=62|isbn=0-313-30063-1}}{{cite book|last=Raat|first=W. Dirk|author2=William H. Beezley|title=Twentieth-century Mexico|publisher=University of Nebraska Press|year=1986|pages=130|isbn=0-8032-8914-6}} Molina Enríquez had helped create the legal mandate for the destruction of the hacienda system and the re-centralization of State power. ==Further reading== *Coffman, Amador. [[Astronaut]]s hold a variety of ranks and positions, and each of these roles carries responsibilities that are essential to the operation of a spacecraft. A spacecraft's cockpit, filled with sophisticated equipment, requires skills differing from those used to manage the scientific equipment on board, and so on. == NASA ranks and positions == === Ranks === Members of the [[NASA Astronaut Corps]] hold one of two ranks. Astronaut Candidate is the rank of those training to be NASA astronauts. Upon graduation, candidates are promoted to Astronaut and receive their [[Astronaut Badge|Astronaut Pin]]. The pin is issued in two grades, silver and gold, with the silver pin awarded to candidates who have successfully completed astronaut training and the gold pin to astronauts who have flown in space. [[Chief of the Astronaut Office]] is a position, not a rank. === Positions === {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:97%;" |- ! style="width:15%;"| Position ! style="width:40%;"| Duties ! style="width:20%;"| Examples ! style="width:25%;"| Comments |- | colspan="4" style="background:Gainsboro;"| [[Project Mercury|Mercury]] |- ! Pilot | Overall mission success | [[Mercury Seven]] | As a single-seat spacecraft, the astronauts who flew the [[Project Mercury#Spacecraft|Mercury]] missions were referred to simply as "Pilots". Mercury Pilots were required to have experience as a pilot of high-performance jet aircraft and to be no more than {{convert|5|ft|11|in|cm}} tall and weigh no more than {{convert|180|lb|kg}}. |- | colspan="4" style="background:Gainsboro;"| [[Project Gemini|Gemini]] |- ! Command Pilot | Overall mission success, safety of crew and spacecraft | [[James McDivitt]] | McDivitt was the first rookie Command Pilot. |- ! Pilot | Serves as systems engineer, copilot, and would perform any other mission objectives such as EVA's during the Gemini program. | [[Ed White (astronaut)|Ed White]] | White was the first American who made an EVA ([[extravehicular activity]]). |- | colspan="4" style="background:Gainsboro;"| [[Apollo program|Apollo]] |- ! Commander | Overall mission success, safety of crew and spacecraft, pilot in command of spacecraft during launch, trans-lunar coast, and earth return coast. Also pilot in command of the Lunar Module. The commander would make the actual descent and landing of LM on the lunar surface, as well as the lunar ascent back to the orbiting CSM. | [[Neil Armstrong]], first man on the Moon Backup Commander: [[Jim Lovell]] commander of [[Apollo 13]] | |- ! Command Module Pilot | Responsible for knowing the CSM and their systems fully. Serve as flight engineer during launch phase while commander would be in full control of the vehicle. Perform navigation and mid-course correction procedures during trans-lunar and trans-earth phases of flight, command pilot of CSM during lunar orbit phase (when the mission commander is in control of the lunar module from separation phase until the LM docked back with CSM in lunar orbit). The CM pilot would also have other objectives during lunar orbit phase such as lunar photography, research and study for future landing sites for subsequent Apollo missions, deploy lunar satellite in some cases, as well as being responsible for relaying messages from mission control if radio contact with the LM was lost or weak, and also responsible for performing an orbital rescue with the LM if it were to malfunction and not be able to perform as needed to rendezvous with CSM as planned for in normal cases, but this never was needed. However, the CM pilot was responsible for docking the two ships together when the LM returned to orbit after being on the surface. | [[Michael Collins (astronaut)|Michael Collins]],
Backup CMP: [[William Anders]] | |- ! Lunar Module Pilot | Flight engineer of [[Apollo Lunar Module]] during descent and ascent of the [[Lunar Module|LM]] also responsible for its systems during all phases of flight between earth and moon. The LMP would callout key information to the commander during the most critical descent and landing phases when all of the commander's attention would be focused out the window and on visually flying the LM to a suitable landing spot on the surface. He would also control the navigation computer and other subsystems of the craft while the commander had hands on the controls to fly the ship down manually the last portion of the descent when manual control was taken over from the computer. | [[Buzz Aldrin]], second man on the moon
Backup LMP: [[Fred Haise]] | Aldrin was the first "Doctor of Philosophy" (technically, "Doctor of Science (Sc.D.)") in Space |- ! Docking Module Pilot | | [[Deke Slayton]], Mercury 7 astronaut | Position only used once during [[Apollo-Soyuz]] joint mission |- | colspan="4" style="background:Gainsboro;"| [[Skylab]] |- ! Commander | Overall mission success, safety of crew and spacecraft | [[Pete Conrad]], first Skylab commander | |- ! Pilot | | [[Paul J. Weitz]] | |- ! Science Pilot | | [[Joseph P. Kerwin]], first American physician in space | |- | colspan="4" style="background:Gainsboro;"| [[Space Shuttle program|Space Shuttle]] |- ! Commander | Overall mission success, safety of crew and Shuttle, maneuvers Shuttle with assistance from Pilot. | [[John Young (astronaut)|John Young]], commander of the first shuttle mission | All Shuttle commanders have prior spaceflight experience.[[Joe Engle]] flew on [[STS-2]] without prior NASA spaceflight experience, but had flown the [[X-15]] into space and had participated in the Shuttle [[Approach and Landing Tests]]. Requires a degree in engineering, biological science, physical science, or mathematics. Must have at least 1000 hours flying experience on a [[jet aircraft]],{{cite web|url=http://www.kidzworld.com/article/3084-becoming-an-astronaut |title=Astronauts | Career | Education | Pilot | Commander | Mission Specialist | NASA | Space Shuttle | Flight - Page 1 |publisher=Kidzworld.com |date= |accessdate=2012-06-09}} and at least 750 simulated landings in the [[Shuttle Training Aircraft]].{{cite interview | title=Charles F. Bolden | date=2004-01-06 | accessdate=6 January 2014 | last=Bolden | first=Charles F. | subjectlink=Charles F. Bolden | interviewer1=Johnson, Sandra| interviewer2=Wright, Rebecca| interviewer3=Ross-Nazzal, Jennifer | work=NASA Johnson Space Center Oral History Project | location=Houston, Texas | url=http://www.jsc.nasa.gov/history/oral_histories/BoldenCF/BoldenCF_1-6-04.htm}} Must pass a NASA Class I space physical to be certified for flight.{{cite web|url=http://www.kidzworld.com/article/3086-becoming-an-astronaut-pg-2 |title=Astronauts | Career | Education | Pilot | Commander | Mission Specialist | NASA | Space Shuttle | Flight - Page 2 |publisher=Kidzworld.com |date=2008-10-07 |accessdate=2012-06-09}} |- ! Pilot | Assist the Commander in maneuvering the Shuttle. May be responsible for release and recovery of satellites. | [[Robert Crippen]], flew the first shuttle mission as pilot | Same education and flight experience requirements as a Commander, but does not need prior spaceflight experience. |- ! Payload Commander (PLC) | A Mission Specialist with additional responsibility for the management of the science or other major payload elements of the mission.{{cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/columbia/crew/profile_michaela.html |title=NASA - Space Shuttle Columbia and Her Crew |publisher=Nasa.gov |date=2006-03-05 |accessdate=2012-06-09}} | [[Story Musgrave]], [[Michael P. Anderson]] | Payload Commanders are always NASA astronauts. |- ! [[Mission Specialist]] (MS) | A NASA astronaut assigned to a Shuttle crew with mission-specific duties. | [[Jerry L. Ross]] and [[Franklin Chang-Diaz]] each flew seven times as Shuttle Mission Specialists. | Must pass a NASA Class II space physical to be certified for flight. |- ! Flight Engineer | A Mission Specialist with additional responsibility of assisting the Pilot and Commander. The FE also keeps track of information from CAPCOM and calls out milestones. | [[Story Musgrave]], [[Michael P. Anderson]] | The FE is always Mission Specialist 2 and sits in the S4 seat on the Shuttle flight deck. |- ! International Mission Specialist | Same as Mission Specialist but may have payload-specific duties assigned by home agency. | [[Hans Schlegel]] | |- ! [[Educator Astronaut Project|Educator Mission Specialist]] | Same as Mission Specialist but with additional education-related duties. | [[Joseph M. Acaba]], first Puerto Rican astronaut | Position created in 2004 as part of the [[Educator Astronaut Project]]. |- ! [[Payload Specialist]] | Technical experts who accompany specific payloads such as a commercial or scientific satellites. | *[[Byron K. Lichtenberg]], first payload specialist *[[Ulf Merbold]], first international payload specialist *[[Charles D. Walker|Charles Walker]], flew three times *[[Ilan Ramon]], last payload specialist | Payload Specialists are non-NASA personnel. The term is also applied to representatives from partner nations such as Saudi Arabia and Mexico who were given the opportunity to fly on the Space Shuttle. |- ! [[Manned Spaceflight Engineer Program|USAF Manned Spaceflight Engineer]] | Same as Payload Specialist, but are military personnel who accompany military payloads. | [[Gary Payton (astronaut)|Gary Payton]] | Payton and [[William A. Pailes]] were the only Manned Spaceflight Engineers to fly before the program's termination in 1988. |- ! [[Spaceflight Participant]] | People who travel aboard space missions coordinated by those agencies who are not part of the crew. | [[Christa McAuliffe]], [[Teacher in Space]], Space Shuttle Challenger disaster | This term serves to distinguish tourists and other special travelers from the career [[astronaut]]s. |} == Russian Federal Space Agency ranks and positions == === Ranks === Russian astronauts are called cosmonauts. After initial training, cosmonauts are assigned as either a test-cosmonaut (космонавт-испытатель, kosmonavt-ispytatel’) or a research-cosmonaut (космонавт-исследователь, kosmonavt-issledovatel’). A test-cosmonaut has a more difficult preparation than a research-cosmonaut and can be the commander or the flight engineer of a spacecraft, while a research-cosmonaut cannot.{{cite web|first=Suzy |last=McHale |url=http://suzymchale.com/ruspace/training.html |title=RuSpace - Suzy's Russian space site |publisher=Suzymchale.com |date= |accessdate=2012-06-09 }} Higher ranks include pilot-cosmonaut, test-cosmonaut instructor, and research-cosmonaut instructor. [[Pilot-Cosmonaut of the Russian Federation]] is a title that is presented to all cosmonauts who fly for the Russian space program. === Positions === {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:97%;" |- ! style="width:10%;"| Position ! style="width:30%;"| Duties ! style="width:30%;"| Examples ! style="width:30%;"| Comments |- | colspan="4" style="background:Gainsboro;"| [[Vostok programme|Vostok]] |- !
